TaskQuestion: Archive is identified by a persistent identifier
TaskShortDescription: This indicator evaluates whether or not the archive is identified by a persistent identifier. A persistent identifier ensures that the metadata will remain findable over time and reduces the risk of broken links.
TaskDetails: The persistence of an identifieris determined by the commitment of the organisation that assigns and manages the identifier, so the evaluation of this indicator needs to take into account the persistence policy of that organisation. Such a commitment could be expressed by a university or research institute, by a research infrastructure or by an organisation that issues formal identifiers, such as the International DOI Foundation. A possible way to evaluate this indicator is to verify that the identifier used for the metadata is listed ina registry service like the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing.

TaskQuestion: Archive is identified by a globally unique identifier
TaskShortDescription: The indicator serves to evaluate whether the identifier of the archive is globally unique, i.e. that there are no two identical identifiers that identify different metadata records.
TaskDetails: Global uniqueness of identifiers should be evaluated based on a description of how identifiers are assigned. Such a description should make it clear that the mechanism for assigning identifiers cannot possibly assign the same identifier to dif ferent resources, or assign an identifier that has already been assigned via some other mechanism/organisation. A possible way to evaluate this indicator is to verif y that the identif ier used f or the data is listed in a registry service like the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing.

A possible way to evaluate this indicator is to verif y that the identif ier used f or the data is listed in a registry service like the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing.

TaskQuestion: Rich metadata of archive is provided to allow discovery
TaskShortDescription: The indicator is about the presence of archive metadata, but also about howmuch metadata is provided and how well the provided metadata supports discovery.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that metadata is provided. The amount of metadata to be provided may also be part of the metadata policy of the repository where the data is published

TaskQuestion: Rich metadata of model is provided to allow discovery
TaskShortDescription: The indicator is about the presence of model metadata, but also about howmuch metadata is provided and how well the provided metadata supports discovery.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that metadata is provided. The amount of metadata to be provided may also be part of the metadata policy of the repository where the data is published

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive includes the identifier for the archive
TaskShortDescription: The indicator deals with the inclusion of the ref erence(i.e. the identifier) of the digital object in the archive metadata so that the digital object can be accessed
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the identifier of the data is included in the metadata elementthat is specified f or that purpose in the metadata standardused, for example in an "about" or "describes" predicate, or a Link Relation16such as "describes"/"describedBy".

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model includes the identifier for the model
TaskShortDescription: The indicator deals with the inclusion of the ref erence(i.e. the identifier) of the digital object in the model metadata so that the digital object can be accessed
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the identifier of the data is included in the metadata elementthat is specified f or that purpose in the metadata standardused, for example in an "about" or "describes" predicate, or a Link Relation16such as "describes"/"describedBy".

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive is offered in such a way that it can be harvested and indexed
TaskShortDescription: The indicator tests whether the archive metadata is offered in such a way that it can be indexed. In some cases, metadata could be provided together with the data to a local institutional repository or to a domain-specific or regional portal, or metadata could be included in a landing page where it can be harvested by a search engine. The indicator remains broad enough on purpose not to limit the way how and by whom the harvesting and indexing of the data might be done.
TaskDetails: Thisindicator can be evaluated by verifying that the metadata is made available f or indexing. This is the case when the metadata is in f act harvested and indexed, for example in a general search engine or in a more restricted index, such as an institutional repository or a discipline-specific portal.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model is offered in such a way that it can be harvested and indexed
TaskShortDescription: The indicator tests whether the model metadata is offered in such a way that it can be indexed. In some cases, metadata could be provided together with the data to a local institutional repository or to a domain-specific or regional portal, or metadata could be included in a landing page where it can be harvested by a search engine. The indicator remains broad enough on purpose not to limit the way how and by whom the harvesting and indexing of the data might be done.
TaskDetails: Thisindicator can be evaluated by verifying that the metadata is made available f or indexing. This is the case when the metadata is in f act harvested and indexed, for example in a general search engine or in a more restricted index, such as an institutional repository or a discipline-specific portal.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive contains information to enable the user to get access to the archive
TaskShortDescription: The indicator ref ers to the information that is necessary to allow the requester to gain access to the digital object. It is about (i) restrictions to access the data (i.e. access to the data may be open, restricted or closed), (ii) the actions to be taken by a person who is interested to access the data, in particular when the data has not been published on the Web or (iii) specifications that the resources are available through specified authentication/authorisationsystem including single sign-on providers such as eduGAIN17or through specialised solutions such as proposed for EPOS18.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the information that is provided in the metadata about (i) access conditionsaccording to the metadata standard used, (ii) inf ormation that describes the actions to be taken. This can be included in the metadata or in some other place, for example on a landing page of the digital object or (iii) the requirements to be satisfied in order to gain access to the data. This may be machine-understandable information in which case the evaluation could be automatedby processing the inf ormation. If it is human-readable information, the evaluator can follow the instructions and verify that this allows access to the data

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model contains information to enable the user to get access to the model
TaskShortDescription: The indicator ref ers to the information that is necessary to allow the requester to gain access to the digital object. It is about (i) restrictions to access the data (i.e. access to the data may be open, restricted or closed), (ii) the actions to be taken by a person who is interested to access the data, in particular when the data has not been published on the Web or (iii) specifications that the resources are available through specified authentication/authorisationsystem including single sign-on providers such as eduGAIN17or through specialised solutions such as proposed for EPOS18.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the information that is provided in the metadata about (i) access conditionsaccording to the metadata standard used, (ii) inf ormation that describes the actions to be taken. TaskQuestion: Archive can be accessed manually (i.e. with human intervention)
TaskShortDescription: The indicator refers to any human interactions that are needed if the requester wants to access the archive. The FAIR principle ref ers mostly to automated interactions where a machine is able to access the data, but there may also be data that requirehuman interactions. This may be important in cases where the data itself contains sensitive inf ormation. Human interaction might involve sending an e-mail to the data owner, or calling by telephone to receive instructions.

TaskQuestion: Model can be accessed manually (i.e. with human intervention)
TaskShortDescription: The indicator refers to any human interactions that are needed if the requester wants to access the model. The FAIR principle ref ers mostly to automated interactions where a machine is able to access the data, but there may also be data that require human interactions. This may be important in cases where the data itself contains sensitive inf ormation. Human interaction might involve sending an e-mail to the data owner, or calling by telephone to receive instructions.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking f or inf ormation about the way that metadata can be accessed with human intervention, either in documentation, f or example in a landing page, or in metadata about the metadata in cases where there is multi-layered metadata, f or example using CatalogRecord in DCAT.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive can be accessed manually (i.e. with human intervention)
TaskShortDescription: The indicator refers to any human interactions that are needed if the requester wants to access the archive metadata. This may be important in cases where the metadata itself contains sensitive inf ormation. TaskQuestion: Archive identifier resolves to a digital object
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the resolutionof the archive identifier. The identifier assigned tothe archive should be associated with a resolution service that enables access to the record.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by checking that the data can be accessed using its identifier. The evaluator or evaluation tool may also want to verify that the resolution delivers the correct record.

TaskQuestion: Model identifier resolves to a digital object
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the resolutionof the mdoel identifier. The identifier assigned tothe model should be associated with a resolution service that enables access to the record.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by checking that the data can be accessed using its identifier. The evaluator or evaluation tool may also want to verify that the resolution delivers the correct record.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive identifier resolves to a metadata of archive record
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the resolutionof the archive metadata identifier. The identifier assigned tothe metadata should be associated with a resolution service that enables access to the metadata record.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by checking that the metadata can be accessed using its identifier. The evaluator or evaluation tool may also want to verify that the resolution delivers the correct metadata record.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model identifier resolves to a metadata of model record
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the resolutionof the model metadata identifier. The identifier assigned tothe metadata should be associated with a resolution service that enables access to the metadata record.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by checking that the metadata can be accessed using its identifier. The evaluator or evaluation tool may also want to verify that the resolution delivers the correct metadata record.

TaskQuestion: Archive is accessible through standardised protocol
TaskShortDescription: The indicator concerns the protocol through which the archive is accessed and requires the protocol to be defined in a standard.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by looking at the way the data can be accessed. Common metadata access protocolsare HTTP and FTP, Atom19, OAI-PMH20and Web Services Metadata Exchange21.

TaskQuestion: Model is accessible through standardised protocol
TaskShortDescription: The indicator concerns the protocol through which the model is accessed and requires the protocol to be defined in a standard.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by looking at the way the data can be accessed. Common metadata access protocolsare HTTP and FTP, Atom19, OAI-PMH20and Web Services Metadata Exchange21.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive is accessed through standardised protocol
TaskShortDescription: The indicator concerns the protocol through which the archive metadata is accessed and requires the protocol to be defined in a standard.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by looking at the way the metadata can be accessed. Common metadata access protocolsare HTTP and FTP, Atom19, OAI-PMH20and Web Services Metadata Exchange21.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model is accessed through standardised protocol
TaskShortDescription: The indicator concerns the protocol through which the model metadata is accessed and requires the protocol to be defined in a standard.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by looking at the way the metadata can be accessed. Common metadata access protocolsare HTTP and FTP, Atom19, OAI-PMH20and Web Services Metadata Exchange21.

TaskQuestion: Archive can be accessed automatically (i.e. by a computer program)
TaskShortDescription: The indicator refers to automated interactions between machines to access the archive. The way machines interact and grant access to the archive will be evaluated by the indicator.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by resolving the linkto the data, e.g. by resolving the persistent identifier and verifying that the data is reached. In the common case that the identifier is an HTTP URI, this can be done using the HTTP GET method. The evaluator or evaluation tool may also want to verify that the resolution delivers the correct data.

TaskQuestion: Model can be accessed automatically (i.e. by a computer program)
TaskShortDescription: The indicator refers to automated interactions between machines to access the model. The way machines interact and grant access to the model will be evaluated by the indicator.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by resolving the linkto the data, e.g. by resolving the persistent identifier and verifying that the data is reached. In the common case that the identifier is an HTTP URI, this can be done using the HTTP GET method. The evaluator or evaluation tool may also want to verify that the resolution delivers the correct data.

TaskQuestion: Archive is accessible through a free access protocol
TaskShortDescription: The indicator tests that theprotocol that enables the requester to access the archive can be f reely used. Such f ree use of the protocol enhances data reusability.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated on the basis of inf ormation provided about whether the use of the protocol is free of charge. Common examples are HTTP and FTP.

TaskQuestion: Model is accessible through a free access protocol
TaskShortDescription: The indicator tests that theprotocol that enables the requester to access the model can be f reely used. Such f ree use of the protocol enhances data reusability.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated on the basis of inf ormation provided about whether the use of the protocol is free of charge. Common examples are HTTP and FTP.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive is accessible through a free access protocol
TaskShortDescription: The indicator tests that theprotocol that enables the requester to access the archive metadata can be f reely used. Such f ree use of the protocol enhances data reusability.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated on the basis of inf ormation provided about whether the use of the protocol is free of charge. Common examples are HTTP and FTP.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model is accessible through a free access protocol
TaskShortDescription: The indicator tests that theprotocol that enables the requester to access the model metadata can be f reely used. Such f ree use of the protocol enhances data reusability.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated on the basis of inf ormation provided about whether the use of the protocol is free of charge. Common examples are HTTP and FTP.

TaskQuestion: Archive is accessible through an access protocol that supports authentication and authorisation
TaskShortDescription: The indicator requires that if the archive or local environment indicates a degree of additional protection then the access protocol must support authentication and authorisation of people and/or machines?
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by assessing whether an authentication and authorisation process is present in the protocol (e.g. HMAC)

TaskQuestion: Model is accessible through an access protocol that supports authentication and authorisation
TaskShortDescription: The indicator requires that if the model or local environment indicates a degree of additional protection then the access protocol must support authentication and authorisation of people and/or machines?
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by assessing whether an authentication and authorisation process is present in the protocol (e.g. HMAC)

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive is guaranteed to remain available after archive is no longer available
TaskShortDescription: The indicator intends to verify that information about a digital object is still available af ter the object has been deleted or otherwise has become unavailable. If possible, the archive metadata that remains available should also indicate why the object is no longeravailable.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated on the basis of information provided about the lif e cycle of metadata and data, which should indicate that the metadata will remain available if the data is no longer available. This inf ormation is likely to be available from the repository where the metadata and data are stored

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model is guaranteed to remain available after model is no longer available
TaskShortDescription: The indicator intends to verify that information about a digital object is still available af ter the object has been deleted or otherwise has become unavailable. If possible, the model metadata that remains available should also indicate why the object is no longeravailable.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated on the basis of information provided about the lif e cycle of metadata and data, which should indicate that the metadata will remain available if the data is no longer available. This inf ormation is likely to be available from the repository where the metadata and data are stored

TaskQuestion: Archive content is expressed in standardised formats
TaskShortDescription: The indicator serves to determine that an appropriate standard is used toexpress knowledge, f or example, controlled vocabularies for subject classifications
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at inf ormation describing the way metadata values are expressed using controlled vocabularies, verifying that the standard used is appropriate f or the domain and the type of digital object. Deciding on the appropriateness of the knowledge representation may be based on its inclusion in a registry like the one developed by FAIRsharing.

TaskShortDescription: The indicator serves to determine that an appropriate standard is used toexpress knowledge, f or example, controlled vocabularies for subject classifications
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at inf ormation describing the way metadata values are expressed using controlled vocabularies, verifying that the standard used is appropriate f or the domain and the type of digital object. Deciding on the appropriateness of the knowledge representation may be based on its inclusion in a registry like the one developed by FAIRsharing.

Deciding on the appropriateness of the knowledge representation may be based on its inclusion in a registry like the one developed by FAIRsharing.

TaskName: CA-RDA-I1-02Archive - to check if needed for archive
TaskQuestion: Archive uses machine-understandable knowledge representation
TaskShortDescription: This indicator focuses on the machine-understandability aspect of the archive. This means that data should be readable and thus interoperable for machines without any requirements such as specific translators or mappings.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by looking at the knowledge representation model used f or the expression of the data. Examples are RDF, OWL, JSON-LD and SKOS. Information about models and formats canbe looked up in a registry like the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing (see f or example : https://fairsharing.org/standards/?q=&selected_facets=type_exact:model/format).

TaskShortDescription: This indicator focuses on the machine-understandability aspect of the model. This means that data should be readable and thus interoperable for machines without any requirements such as specific translators or mappings.

TaskQuestion: The files contained in the Archive use FAIR-compliant vocabularies
TaskShortDescription: The indicator requires the vocabularyused f or the archive to conform to the FAIR principles, and at least be documented and resolvable using globally unique and persistent identifiers. The documentation needs to be easily findable and accessible.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verifying that each of the vocabularies used in the metadata is documented and resolvable using globally unique and persistent identif iers, with the documentation being easily f indable and accessible. Typically, the reference to the specificationof the vocabularies used will be included in the documentation of the digital object or the repository where it is kept

TaskQuestion: Model uses FAIR-compliant vocabularies
TaskShortDescription: The indicator requires the vocabularyused f or the model to conform to the FAIR principles, and at least be documented and resolvable using globally unique and persistent identifiers. The documentation needs to be easily findable and accessible.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verifying that each of the vocabularies used in the metadata is documented and resolvable using globally unique and persistent identif iers, with the documentation being easily f indable and accessible. Typically, the reference to the specificationof the vocabularies used will be included in the documentation of the digital object or the repository where it is kept

TaskQuestion: Archive includes references to other data
TaskShortDescription: The indicator is about the way that the archive is connected to other metadata, for example through links to inf ormation about organisations, people, places, projects or time periods that are related to the digital object that the metadata describes.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the occurrence of ref erences to other metadata, for example ORCID26for people or Geonames27for places.

TaskQuestion: Model includes references to other data
TaskShortDescription: The indicator is about the way that the model is connected to other metadata, for example through links to inf ormation about organisations, people, places, projects or time periods that are related to the digital object that the metadata describes.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the occurrence of ref erences to other metadata, for example ORCID26for people or Geonames27for places.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive includes references to other metadata of archive
TaskShortDescription: The indicator is about the way that the archive metadata is connected to other metadata, for example through links to inf ormation about organisations, people, places, projects or time periods that are related to the digital object that the metadata describes.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the occurrence of ref erences to other metadata, for example ORCID26for people or Geonames27for places.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model includes references to other metadata of model
TaskShortDescription: The indicator is about the way that the model metadata is connected to other metadata, for example through links to inf ormation about organisations, people, places, projects or time periods that are related to the digital object that the metadata describes.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the occurrence of ref erences to other metadata, for example ORCID26for people or Geonames27for places.

TaskQuestion: Archive includes qualified references to other data
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way the archive is connected to other data, for example linking to previous or related research data that provides additional context to the data. Please note that this is not about the link from the metadata to the data it describes; that link is considered in principle F3 and in indicator RDA-F3-01M.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the presence of references to other data in the metadata

TaskQuestion: Model includes qualified references to other data
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way the model is connected to other data, for example linking to previous or related research data that provides additional context to the data. Please note that this is not about the link from the metadata to the data it describes; that link is considered in principle F3 and in indicator RDA-F3-01M.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the presence of references to other data in the metadata

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive includes references to other data (models or archives)
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way the archive metadata is connected to other data, for example linking to previous or related research data that provides additional context to the data. Please note that this is not about the link from the metadata to the data it describes; that link is considered in principle F3 and in indicator RDA-F3-01M.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the presence of references to other data in the metadata

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model includes references to other data (archives or models)
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way the model metadata is connected to other data, for example linking to previous or related research data that provides additional context to the data. Please note that this is not about the link from the metadata to the data it describes; that link is considered in principle F3 and in indicator RDA-F3-01M.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the presence of references to other data in the metadata

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive includes qualified references to other metadata
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way the archive metadata is connected to other metadata, for example to descriptions of related resources that provide additional context to the data. The references need to be qualified which means that the relationship of the related resource is specified, f or example person Y is the author ofdataset X.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the presence of ref erences with specification of the relationship that the related resource has to the described resource.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model includes qualified references to other metadata
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way the model metadata is connected to other metadata, for example to descriptions of related resources that provide additional context to the data. The references need to be qualified which means that the relationship of the related resource is specified, f or example person Y is the author ofdataset X.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the presence of ref erences with specification of the relationship that the related resource has to the described resource.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive include qualified references to other data
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way the archive metadata is connected to other data. The ref erences need to be qualified which means that the relationship role of the related resource is specified, for example dataset X is derived from dataset Y.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the presence of ref erences with specification of the relationship role that the related resource has with the described resource

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model include qualified references to other data
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way the model metadata is connected to other data. The ref erences need to be qualified which means that the relationship role of the related resource is specified, for example dataset X is derived from dataset Y.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by looking at the presence of ref erences with specification of the relationship role that the related resource has with the described resource

TaskQuestion: Plurality of accurate and relevant attributes of archive are provided to allow reuse
TaskShortDescription: The indicator concerns the quantity but also the quality of metadata provided in order to enhance data reusability
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated with the help of standards registries such as the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing (see f or example: https://fairsharing.org/standards/?q=/format&selected_facets=type_exact:reporting%20guideline)

TaskQuestion: Plurality of accurate and relevant attributes of model are provided to allow reuse
TaskShortDescription: The indicator concerns the quantity but also the quality of metadata provided in order to enhance data reusability
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated with the help of standards registries such as the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing (see f or example: https://fairsharing.org/standards/?q=/format&selected_facets=type_exact:reporting%20guideline)

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive includes information about the licence under which the archive can be reused
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the information that is provided in the archive metadata related to the conditions (e.g. obligations, restrictions) under which data can be reused. In the absence of licenceinformation, data cannot be reused.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by looking in the metadata f or licence inf ormation. This inf ormation may be in human-readable text; machine-understandability of the information is covered in indicator RDA-R1.1-03M.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model includes information about the licence under which the model can be reused
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the information that is provided in the model metadata related to the conditions (e.g. obligations, restrictions) under which data can be reused. In the absence of licenceinformation, data cannot be reused.
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by looking in the metadata f or licence inf ormation. This inf ormation may be in human-readable text; machine-understandability of the information is covered in indicator RDA-R1.1-03M.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive refers to a standard reuse licence
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires the reference to the conditions of reuse to be a standard licence, rather than a locally defined licence.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the licence is indeed a standard licence. Examples ofstandard licences are: Creative Commons licences, Open Data Commons.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model refers to a standard reuse licence
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires the reference to the conditions of reuse to be a standard licence, rather than a locally defined licence.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the licence is indeed a standard licence. Examples ofstandard licences are: Creative Commons licences, Open Data Commons.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive refers to a machine-understandable reuse licence
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way that the reuse licence is expressed. Rather than being a human-readable text, the licence should be expressed in such a way that it can be processed by machines, without human intervention, for example in automated searches.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the link to the licence resolves to a machine-understandable expression of the conditions. An example of such a machine-understandable expression is the RDF expression of Creative Commons licences, or the various serialisations of the Open Data Rights Language (ODRL).

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model refers to a machine-understandable reuse licence
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way that the reuse licence is expressed. Rather than being a human-readable text, the licence should be expressed in such a way that it can be processed by machines, without human intervention, for example in automated searches.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the link to the licence resolves to a machine-understandable expression of the conditions. An example of such a machine-understandable expression is the RDF expression of Creative Commons licences, or the various serialisations of the Open Data Rights Language (ODRL).

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive includes provenance information according to community-specific standards
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires the archive metadata to include inf ormation about the provenance of the data, i.e. information about the origin, history or workflow that generated the data, in a way that is compliant with the standards that are used in the community for which the data is curated
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the provenance informationf ollows the community standard. A RDA-endorsed service like FAIRsharingcould be helpful to identify the relevant standards.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model includes provenance information according to community-specific standards
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires the model metadata to include inf ormation about the provenance of the data, i.e. information about the origin, history or workflow that generated the data, in a way that is compliant with the standards that are used in the community for which the data is curated
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the provenance informationf ollows the community standard. A RDA-endorsed service like FAIRsharingcould be helpful to identify the relevant standards.

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive includes provenance information according to a cross-community language
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the archive metadata provides provenance inf ormation according to a cross-domainlanguage.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by assessing whether a cross-domain language is used f or provenance information (such as PROV-O)

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model includes provenance information according to a cross-community language
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the model metadata provides provenance inf ormation according to a cross-domainlanguage.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by assessing whether a cross-domain language is used f or provenance information (such as PROV-O)

TaskQuestion: Archive complies with a community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the archive complies with community standards.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verif ying that the metadata f ollows a community standard. A service like the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing or the Metadata Standards Catalogcould be helpful to identify the relevant standards

TaskQuestion: Model complies with a community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the model complies with community standards.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verif ying that the metadata f ollows a community standard. A service like the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing or the Metadata Standards Catalogcould be helpful to identify the relevant standards

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive complies with a community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the archive metadata complies with community standards.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verif ying that the metadata f ollows a community standard. A service like the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing or the Metadata Standards Catalogcould be helpful to identify the relevant standards

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model complies with a community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the model metadata complies with community standards.
TaskDetails: The indicator can be evaluated by verif ying that the metadata f ollows a community standard. A service like the RDA-endorsed FAIRsharing or the Metadata Standards Catalogcould be helpful to identify the relevant standards

TaskQuestion: Archive is expressed in compliance with a machine-understandable community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the archive follows a community standard that has a machine-understandable expression
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the community standard used f or the metadata has a machine-understandable expression

TaskQuestion: Model is expressed in compliance with a machine-understandable community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the model follows a community standard that has a machine-understandable expression
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the community standard used f or the metadata has a machine-understandable expression

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive is expressed in compliance with a machine-understandable community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the archive metadata follows a community standard that has a machine-understandable expression
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the community standard used f or the metadata has a machine-understandable expression

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model is expressed in compliance with a machine-understandable community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the model metadata follows a community standard that has a machine-understandable expression
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the community standard used f or the metadata has a machine-understandable expression

TaskQuestion: Metadata of archive is expressed in compliance with a machine-understandable cross-community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the archive metadata follows a cross-community standard that has a machine-understandable expression
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the cross-community standard used f or the metadata has a machine-understandable expression

TaskQuestion: Metadata of model is expressed in compliance with a machine-understandable cross-community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the model metadata follows a cross-community standard that has a machine-understandable expression
TaskDetails: This indicator can be evaluated by verifying that the cross-community standard used f or the metadata has a machine-understandable expression

TaskQuestion: Metadata is identified by a persistent identifier
TaskShortDescription: This indicator examines whether the metadata for the resource uploaded to the NFDI4Health study hub is assigned a persistent identifier. The use of a persistent identifier is crucial as it ensures the long-term findability of this specific metadata, significantly reducing the likelihood of encountering broken links and enhancing the resource's accessibility over time
TaskDetails: The CSH demands an ID (resource.identifier) when uploading metadata. It can be generated by the study hub or entered based on a schema, such as DOI and DRKS. Thus the indicator is implicitly passed.

TaskQuestion: Metadata is identified by a globally unique identifier
TaskShortDescription: The identifier used for the metadata is listed in a registry service
TaskDetails: The CSH demands an ID (resource.identifier) when uploading metadata. It can be generated by the study hub or entered based on a schema, such as DOI and DRKS. Thus the indicator is implicitly passed.

TaskQuestion: Rich metadata is provided to allow discovery
TaskShortDescription: The repository provides evidence that resource discovery metadata is sufficient for their designated community of users
TaskDetails: Check if the mandatory attributes exist and have, if applicable, allowed values.

TaskQuestion: Metadata includes the identifier for the data
TaskShortDescription: The indicator deals with the inclusion of the reference (i.e. the identifier) of the resources in the metadata so that the resources can be accessed. The FAIR principle F3, which emphasizes that metadata should clearly and explicitly include the identifier of the data they describe, is broadly applicable to any type of resource that can be distinctly identified and referenced. This principle ensures that each piece of metadata is directly linked to its corresponding data or document, thereby enhancing the findability and accessibility of research resources.
TaskDetails: Check if the list of resource ids contains an identifier that either has the relation A describes B or A is metadata for B. Also evaluate if the provided identifier follows an commonly accepted identifier scheme and is registered.

TaskQuestion: Metadata is offered in such a way that it can be harvested and indexed
TaskShortDescription: This metric pertains to the methods by which metadata is made accessible or delivered in a standardized and machine-readable format. To evaluate this metric, it is essential to grasp the functionalities provided by the data repository hosting the data. Metadata might be accessible through various channels. For instance, when resource is stored in a repository, this repository could distribute its metadata via a metadata harvesting protocol (such as OAI-PMH) and/or a web service.
TaskDetails: This is a general indicator that has to be evaluated for the CSH as a platform. Metadata can be retrieved in a JSON format. The landing page provides a link in the footer that leads to the API. Thus, this indicator is implicitly passed.

TaskQuestion: Metadata contains information to enable the user to get access to the data or resources.
TaskShortDescription: The indicator refers to the information that is necessary to allow the requester to gain access to the digital object. It is (i) about whether there are restrictions to access the data (i.e. access to the data may be open, restricted or closed), (ii) the actions to be taken by a person who is interested to access the data, in particular when the data has not been published on the Web and (iii) specifications that the resources are available through.
TaskDetails: Check if the attribute chain design.dataSharingPlan.generally results in the value Yes, there is a plan to share the ressource. Beyond that, it is not feasible to evaluate the free text automatically. Thus, it is not possible to fully evaluate if this indicator can pass without human interaction.

TaskQuestion: Metadata identifier resolves to a metadata record
TaskShortDescription: This metric pertains to the clarity of the metadata identifier. The identifier given to the metadata must be linked to a resolution service that facilitates access to the metadata document.The indicator refers to any human interactions that are needed if the requester wants to access the digital object. This FAIR principle refers mostly to automated interactions where a machine is able to access the digital object, but there may also be digital objects that require human interactions, such as clicking on a link on a landing page, sending an e-mail to the data owner, or even calling by telephone.
TaskDetails: In general the CSH provides the option to search for metadata based on its identifier. For sets that uploaded a check if the resource.identifier resolves via the logical URL. This indicator cannot be evaluated, if the FAIRness is evaluated during the creation of the metadata set. In this case the indicator is set as not applicable.

TaskQuestion: Metadata is accessed through standardised protocol
TaskShortDescription: In general the CSH provides the option to search for metadata based on its identifier. For sets that uploaded a check if the resource.identifier resolves via the logical URL. This indicator cannot be evaluated, if the FAIRness is evaluated during the creation of the metadata set. In this case the indicator is set as not applicable.
TaskDetails: In general the CSH provides the option to search for metadata based on its identifier. For sets that uploaded a check if the resource.identifier resolves via the logical URL. This indicator cannot be evaluated, if the FAIRness is evaluated during the creation of the metadata set. In this case the indicator is set as not applicable.

TaskQuestion: Metadata is accessible through a free access protocol
TaskShortDescription: In general the CSH provides the option to search for metadata based on its identifier. For sets that uploaded a check if the resource.identifier resolves via the logical URL. This indicator cannot be evaluated, if the FAIRness is evaluated during the creation of the metadata set. In this case the indicator is set as not applicable.
TaskDetails: In general the CSH provides the option to search for metadata based on its identifier. For sets that uploaded a check if the resource.identifier resolves via the logical URL. This indicator cannot be evaluated, if the FAIRness is evaluated during the creation of the metadata set. In this case the indicator is set as not applicable.

TaskQuestion: Metadata is guaranteed to remain available after data is no longer available
TaskShortDescription: In general the CSH provides the option to search for metadata based on its identifier. For sets that uploaded a check if the resource.identifier resolves via the logical URL. This indicator cannot be evaluated, if the FAIRness is evaluated during the creation of the metadata set. In this case the indicator is set as not applicable.
TaskDetails: In general the CSH provides the option to search for metadata based on its identifier. For sets that uploaded a check if the resource.identifier resolves via the logical URL. This indicator cannot be evaluated, if the FAIRness is evaluated during the creation of the metadata set. In this case the indicator is set as not applicable.

TaskQuestion: Metadata uses knowledge representation expressed in standardised format
TaskShortDescription: The indicator serves to determine that an appropriate standard is used to express knowledge, for example, controlled vocabularies for subject classifications.
TaskDetails: This is a general question. For each attribute the allowed values should be checked whether they adhere to a fitting vocabulary.

TaskQuestion: Metadata uses machine-understandable knowledge representation
TaskShortDescription: This is a general question. For each attribute the allowed values should be checked whether they adhere to a fitting vocabulary.
TaskDetails: Generally the CSH exports a metadata object as an JSON object upon API request. Thus, this indicator implicitly passes.

TaskQuestion: Metadata uses FAIR-compliant vocabularies
TaskShortDescription: The indicator requires the vocabulary used for the metadata to conform to the FAIR principles, and at least be documented and resolvable using globally unique and persistent identifiers. The documentation needs to be easily findable and accessible.
TaskDetails: Implicitly fulfilled for every resource registered in the CHSH (FHIR representation in SIMPLIFIER)

TaskQuestion: Metadata includes references to other metadata
TaskShortDescription: The indicator is about the way that metadata is connected to other metadata, for example through links to information about organizations, people, places, projects or time periods that are related to the digital object that the metadata describes.
TaskDetails: Implement a check if identifier with a fitting relation type are resolvable for the registry of the specific scheme. Allowed schemes are DOI, URL, arXiv, EAN13, EISSN, Handle, ISBN, ISTC and LISSN. Most likely not all schemas can be used for metadata.

TaskQuestion: Metadata includes references to other data
TaskShortDescription: This indicator examines how metadata interlinks with additional data sources to enhance its context, such as connections to preceding or related research data.
TaskDetails: Implement a check if identifiers with a fitting relation type are resolvable for the registry of the specific scheme. Allowed schemes are DOI, URL, arXiv, EAN13, EISSN, Handle, ISBN, ISTC and LISSN.

TaskQuestion: Metadata includes qualified references to other metadata
TaskShortDescription: This measure focuses on how metadata links to additional metadata, such as descriptions of associated resources that offer further insight into the data. The connections must be explicitly defined, indicating the nature of the relationship with the related resource, such as specifying that person Y authored dataset X.
TaskDetails: Implement a check if identifiers with a fitting relation type are resolvable for the registry of the specific scheme. Allowed schemes are DOI, URL, arXiv, EAN13, EISSN, Handle, ISBN, ISTC and LISSN.

TaskQuestion: Metadata includes qualified references to other data
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way metadata is connected to other data, for example linking to previous or related research data that provides additional context to the data. Please note that this is not about the link from the metadata to the data it describes; that link is considered in principle F3 and in indicator RDA-F3-01M.
TaskDetails: Implement a check if identifiers with a fitting relation type are resolvable for the registry of the specific scheme. Allowed schemes are DOI, URL, arXiv, EAN13, EISSN, Handle, ISBN, ISTC and LISSN.

TaskQuestion: Plurality of accurate and relevant attributes are provided to allow reuse
TaskShortDescription: The indicator concerns the quantity but also the quality of metadata provided in order to enhance data reusability.
TaskDetails: Check the existence of all applicable attributes.

TaskQuestion: Metadata includes information about the licence under which the data can be reused
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the information that is provided in the metadata related to the conditions (e.g. obligations, restrictions) under which data can be reused. It about the presence of licensing information, making sure that anyone accessing the data understands the permissions and restrictions placed on the data by the data owner. Key Element: The presence of licensing information, but not necessarily in a standardized or machine-readable format.
TaskDetails: Check the existence of all applicable attributes.

TaskQuestion: Metadata refers to a standard reuse licence
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires the reference to the conditions of reuse to be a standard license, rather than a locally defined license. This goes a step further by specifying that the license mentioned in the metadata should not be just any license, but a standard, widely recognized license. This ensures that the terms of use are well-understood and consistent, reducing ambiguity for users who want to reuse the data. Key Element: Use of a standard, widely-recognized license to ensure clarity and consistency in understanding the terms of reuse.
TaskDetails: Check the label of the license whether it fits to the list above.

TaskQuestion: Metadata refers to a machine-understandable reuse licence
TaskShortDescription: This indicator is about the way that the reuse license is expressed. Rather than being a human-readable text, the license should be expressed in such a way that it can be processed by machines, without human intervention, for example in automated searches. This is crucial for the automated processing of datasets, allowing software systems to understand and potentially enforce the licensing terms without human intervention. Key Element: The inclusion of license information in a format that can be understood and processed by machines, enabling automated systems to recognize and act on the licensing terms
TaskDetails: Check whether the license refers to one of the following machine readable licenses: CC0 1.0, CC BY 4.0, CC BY-NC 4.0, CC BY-SA 4.0, CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

TaskQuestion: Metadata includes provenance information according to community-specific standards
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires the metadata to include information about the provenance of the data, i.e. information about the origin, history or workflow that generated the data, in a way that is compliant with the standards that are used in the community in which the data is produced.
TaskDetails: Check if the necessary attributes are provided in the metadata.

TaskQuestion: Metadata includes provenance information according to a cross-community language
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the metadata provides provenance information according to a cross-domain language.

TaskQuestion: Metadata complies with a community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that metadata complies with community standards
TaskDetails: The indicator addresses the general policy of the platform. Most likely it will implicitly pass.

TaskQuestion: Metadata is expressed in compliance with a machine-understandable community standard
TaskShortDescription: This indicator requires that the metadata follows a community standard that has a machine-understandable expression.
TaskDetails: Generally, the CSH provides an export of the metadata in FHIR format. Thus, this indicator implicitly passes.
